Utterance: Hi again, I'm glad to see you back today! How have you been since our last session?
Hey, Ellie! I've been alright, just keeping busy.
That’s good to hear. Last time, you mentioned playing guitar and hanging out with friends. Have you had any opportunities to do that recently?
Yeah, I actually played with some friends last weekend. It was fun!
That sounds great! How did it feel to play with them?
Really good, like a stress relief.
I can imagine. Music can be such a powerful outlet. Have you noticed any changes in your mood or energy levels after playing?
Definitely. I feel lighter, you know? Less weighed down.
Classified_Subsection: History of Present Illness (HPI): Physiological Observations

Utterance: That’s wonderful! It seems like music is a positive coping mechanism for you. Would you like to explore that further?
Sure, I could talk about it.
Great! How does playing music help you when you’re feeling agitated or stressed?
It just takes my mind off things. I can focus on the chords and forget about everything else.
That sounds very therapeutic. Have you considered incorporating that into your daily routine?
I haven't thought about it, but it could help.
Maybe we can set a goal for you to play a little each day. How does that sound?
I think I could do that.
Awesome! So, let’s aim for at least 15 minutes a day. We can check in on that next session.
Okay, I can manage that.
How about your relationship with your girlfriend? You mentioned she sometimes frustrates you. Have you had any conversations with her about that?
Not really. I don’t want to start an argument.
I understand. Communication can be tricky. What if we brainstorm some ways to express your feelings without it turning into an argument?
That might help.
Excellent! What’s one specific situation where you felt frustrated with her recently?
Well, she was talking over me during dinner the other night.
That sounds frustrating. How did that make you feel?
I felt ignored, like my opinions didn’t matter.
It’s understandable to feel that way. How do you think she would respond if you brought this up with her?
I think she’d get defensive.
That’s a possibility. What if you approached it from a place of curiosity instead? Like asking how she feels about conversations?
That might work. I could ask her why she does that.
Yes! Framing it as a question could open up a dialogue. Would you feel comfortable trying that?
Yeah, I think I could do that.
Great! Let’s also set a goal for you to have that conversation this week.
Okay, I’ll try.
Wonderful! Now, you mentioned feeling overwhelmed at times. What else contributes to that feeling?
Just work, I guess. It can be stressful.
What aspects of your work are most stressful for you?
Just deadlines and expectations. I feel like I’m always racing against the clock.
That sounds tough. Have you tried any strategies to manage that stress?
Not really. I just push through.
It might be helpful to explore some time management techniques or relaxation exercises. Would you be interested in that?
Yeah, I’d be open to it.
Perfect! We can work on some techniques together. For now, how about we focus on one small thing you can do to relieve stress?
Maybe taking breaks?
Absolutely! Let’s set a goal for you to take at least one break during your workday.
Sounds doable.
Great! We’ll review how that goes next time. Is there anything else you’d like to discuss today?
No, I think we covered a lot.
I agree! You’ve made some great goals for yourself. I look forward to hearing about your progress.
Thanks, Ellie!
You’re welcome! Take care and see you next time!
Bye!
